div.p: Training, for me it was the training, the initial training before you become a full-time Fire Fighter you do a 12 week course
and I always say you see when you’re doing something once you know how to do something it’s easy, when something is brand new to you
it’s hard that’s when people say “what’s the hardest part of your job?” it’s not putting out fires it was knowing how to put fires out
knowing how to rescue people from cars, now I know what I’m doing I can do it in my sleep... Not in a show-off way but
you know what I’m trying to say so yeah beforehand the training was the hardest bit because I didn’t know how to do these things
so that was the hardest part of the job for me.
The actual job itself is the assessments, I hate assessments, put me under assessment and I quiver and I’ll probably fail it
but if you don’t tell me it’s an assessment I’ll fly through it so that’s probably what I least like... There is a, not a lot every day but
there is a fair bit of assessment just to make sure you know you’re still able to do the job like you can and stuff like that and I don’t
like assessments even when I pass with flying colours I still don’t like it.
